subject: Re: [junit] Test implementation
msgSnippet: ... Yes. Someone mentioned that here several months ago and I remember discussing how the two patterns were equivalent. I haven t tried using Parameterized
messageBody:
Mark Van Peteghem wrote:
> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
> > popmanse wrote:
> >
> > >
> > > If you define an interface, what is the best strategy to test all
> > > implementing classes.
> >
> > Google Abstract Test Case, and especially read any hits at c2.com.
>
> I often use the Parameterized Test Case instead. Just give an instance
> of each class as a parameter. It allows me to test several classes that
> implement the same interface in just one test case; with the Abstract
> Test Case pattern you have to write a test case for every class.

Yes. Someone mentioned that here several months ago and I remember
discussing how the two patterns were equivalent. I haven't tried using
Parameterized Test Case for this--mostly because I haven't written these
kinds of tests in a while--but I'll try to keep it in mind for next
time. I always like to try these things out, especially when I write
about them. :)

Thanks for the reminder.

<snip />
> However, it shouldn't be used in every case. If you want to test
> behavior that is specific to one or more classes, but not all, you'll
> need the Abstract Test Case. Also, if an interface is implemented by
> many classes in different projects, e.g. Enumerator, it shouldn't be
> used either; I don't know why, it just feels bad :-).

"It feels bad" is often good enough for me.
